metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant charged with three brothers-in-law, Bayyarapu Butchiah, Bayyarapu Chandriah, and Bayyarapu Kotayya, for offences under Section 302 (murder of Irlapati Ramayya), 325 (grievous hurt to Ankayya, P.W. 2), and 323 (simple injury to China Veerayya, P.W. 1).
Incident alleged at about 4.30 p.m. on 15-6-69 in front of house of Vipparla Peda Veerayya in Village Vipparla, District Guntur, Andhra Pradesh.
Sessions Judge of Guntur acquitted all accused, attaching considerable importance to delay in lodging FIR at 10.30 p.m. on 15-6-69 at Police Station, Sattonapalli, 13 miles away.
Prosecution explanation for FIR delay: wife and relations of deceased busy trying to get medical attention for deceased.

Andhra Pradesh High Court on appeal convicted appellant under Section 302 (life imprisonment), Sections 325 and 323; convicted other three accused under Sections 323 and 324 (fine Rs. 150/- or 3 months RI).
No blood found near Neem tree in front of house of P.W. 3, Peda Veerayya, alleged scene.
Trunk of Neem tree 5-6 ft high, no lathis could be lifted without obstruction by branches.
Site plan showed stones lying at some distance from scene.
Independent witnesses available but not examined; admitted in Committing Magistrate's Court by P.W. 1 but new version at trial.
Appellant had four injuries on head, possibly caused by stones; belated explanation by P.W. 4 that he caused them by stone throwing.
Witnesses gave varying times for occurrence: between noon and just before sunset, described by reference to bars before sunset, sun red nearing sunset.
Variations in place: Ankayya P.W. 2 beaten at 10-15 yds, 60-70 yds, or 1-2 yds from P.W. 3's house.

Post-mortem injuries on deceased: Lacerated injury scalp 8 cm x 1 cm over left parietal; cephalo hematoma; contusion left forearm; three small abrasions below right knee. Dissection: comminuted depressed fracture, etc. Scalp covered with blood.
Prosecution version: appellant beat deceased on head; another poked chest then left hand; another blow on forehead (not found); fourth on left side head above ear. Only two head injuries actually.
Dispute over possession and construction of house; 400 stones collected for repairs. Prior obstruction by appellant, beat Sayamma and mother. Constable came around noon on day of occurrence.
Village Munsif not informed; deceased not taken to nearest dispensary.
P.W.1,2,3,4,10,11 relations of deceased; P.W.5,6 treated as independent but urged partisan.
Appellant counsel suggested real occurrence: stone pelting by two sides during day, both sides injured.

legal_issues.text: Whether delay in FIR unexplained and vitiates prosecution case.
Explanation for no blood at scene, tree obstruction, stones nearby, unexamined witnesses, injuries on appellant, time/place variations.
Consistency of prosecution version with medical evidence on injuries and bleeding.
Whether High Court rightly interfered with Sessions Judge's acquittal.

petitioner_arguments.text: P.W.1,2,3,4,10,11 relations, interested; P.W.5,6 wrongly independent.
Real occurrence: stone pelting by two sides; supported by no blood near tree, high tree trunk, stones in site plan, unexamined independents, appellant injuries, time variations, place variations.
Belated explanation for appellant injuries incredible given prosecution case of accused aggression and P.W.4 youth/fear.

respondent_arguments.text: Absence of blood explained by deceased's head gear; hematoma does not produce much bleeding.

court_reasoning.text: FIR delay sufficiently explained by medical attention efforts.
No blood at scene significant; injuries would produce considerable bleeding, scalp covered with blood per doctor; head gear explanation feeble.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absence of blood carries significance ignored by High Court.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution account mismatches medical evidence: no forehead blow injury, only two head injuries not four, knee abrasions from fall.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Account does not fit medical evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Time/place uncertainties, unexplained appellant injuries, no report to Munsif, no dispensary visit suggest prosecution hiding something like stone throwing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Features cast reasonable doubt on prosecution version.

court_reasoning.text: In appeal against acquittal, appellate court must attach due weight to trial court's assessment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court did not comprehensively appreciate all features.

holdings.text: Not satisfied that High Court rightly interfered with acquittal; reasonable doubt on prosecution version.

precedents_cited.relevance: Well established principle: in appeal against acquittal, appellate court ought to attach due weight to trial court's evidence assessment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged; convictions under these sections by High Court

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court's conviction of appellant, restored Sessions Judge's acquittal, finding High Court erred in interfering without comprehensive appreciation of evidence casting reasonable doubt.

key_quotes.text: We are, therefore, not satisfied that the High Court had rightly interfered with the order of acquittal passed by the Trial Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is well established that, in an appeal against acquittal, the appellate Court ought to attach due weight to the assessment of evidence by the Trial Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Hence, absence of blood from the alleged place of occurrence appears to US to carry a significance which the High Court ignored.
key_quotes.speaker: court
